figure.p: I shall have a fine haul amongst these Fellows.

div.head: A FARMER just return'd from Meeting on THANKSGIVING DAY.
PROLOGUE.
div.l: [TO night the Muse attempts to show
The Miser and the aukward Beau;
Where Dan. and Joth. together join,
On sumptuous dish with Father dine.
While Mother she the table sets,
Both Sal. and Mat. assist her next;
Next Lyon he puts in his clame,
And Mother thinks him much to blame▪
She in a passion gives a kick,
Father he being fond of Jack,
Permitted the poor puppy in,
To lap the gravy spilt—quite clean.
Master and Jack always agreed,
He taught him well to say his creed,
And all the words that e'er they had,
Was Paper Money's being bad.
Master insists and makes it so,
That Paper Money wou'd not do▪
Jack he insists, and says no more,
But such examples hurts the Poor.]

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: JACK, take care of the horses, give 'em some of that best rowen,

sp.speaker: JACK.
sp.p: Yesse, Sir.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p: Well, how does Father do— and all your folks?—'Tis quite cold.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Why thank ye child▪ how do you do?—Mat. Draw a mug of cyder, put a good stout pepper-pad in't, heat it well— I feel quite chilly myself. Why I have got good cyder enough; and this year intend to take care of't. Why Jonathan I have been offered five dollars a barrel, and wouldn't look at it, it will fetch me fifteen in the spring.

sp.speaker: JONATHAN.
sp.p:
Yes, Father, that it will, and that won't be near so dear as rum is now in town: I am glad we can say this of the town folks, that we a • e even with them now, only that we should have six Continental dollars
for a load of wood; I'll sell no more for five, I know.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Never fear, never fear, Jonathan, the times are now in our hands, and if we don't improve this opportunity I don't see which way in the world we could ever answer to ourselves with a good conscience.— Hem. Daughter Sarah my service t'ye.

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Thank'e, pray Father.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p: Father your health; Mother yours; herest'e all. [Drinks.] This is right down good cyder as ever man needs drink.

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Yes, Jotham, 'tis, and Mother's pudding looks charming too.

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.p: Come Father, dinner's ready.

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: Come, You, do sit down, all sit down, sit down, the pudding will get cold, and then 'twill be good for nothing.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Well, come let's crave a bles • sing. [The Farmer proceeds to crave a blessing▪ in the run of which he pities the poor and needy thro'out the world.]

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: Come cut for yourselves, I am quite ashamed of my pudding; I think it is the poorest that ever I made; however I don't care, as the times is I believe the town folks wou'd jump at a bit on't poor as it is.

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Why 'tis said that scornful dogs sometimes jump▪ at a dirty pudding.

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: Why Sarah! I'm sure my pudding isn't dirty, I never was reckoned a slut in all my life.

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Oh Mother! I don't mean • o, only that the town folks us'd to scorn every thing but the best, but now they'd be glad even of a crust of your pudding. I expect some of them along to-morrow or next day begging as the Indians us'd to do the day after thanksgiving. I can't but laugh to see how foolish they'l look.—He! he! he!

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! It would be a pretty sight too, Sarah. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Well, I can't but laugh too. Ha! ha! ha! Draw another mug of cyder; take two cups with you.

sp.speaker: JACK.
sp.p: Well Masser, I don't tink 'tis fair ting when poor fok he canno get no noting in he belly; Masser every ting, I do • o no what Masser mean; he pray, he pray, he 〈◊〉 Lord he pity poor ebery where; he no g • v • , he no selle; What he du? Masser got 〈◊〉 enuf, wheat enuf, cyder enuf, ebery ting enuf; Jack he trash, he trash, dis bin full, dat bin full, ebery bin full, poor fok he no lette have, what he du, what poor fok du▪ ah Masser! Jack pitty poor fok.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Why you black Bastard, han't you victuals enough to stop your mouth?

sp.speaker: JACK.
sp.p: Yesse, Sir, only pity poor fok cause he got no round dollar.

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: Well, what's that to you whether 'tis round or square so you live well? There's a hundred mechanics don't live half so well as you do.—

sp.speaker: JACK.
sp.p: I no dat, Masser.

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: I do wish our Jack wou'd mind his own business, and not be always a talking of things that don't concern him at all.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Come Wife, bring on the goose, else I sha'n't have no room for't; I've been oblig'd to unbutton to let in the beef.— Come, who among you can remember the text?—Take care! don't grease my Sabbath-day coat, You.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p:
I can't remember the chap •• r exactly, Father, but I think the words was 〈◊〉
▪ A • ab of dove's dung was sold for— I f • rget▪ for how much—but our Minister preach'd quite a good sermon, and stuck 〈◊〉 down▪ well to his text.

I thought he seem'd greatly 〈…〉 but my child was so tensome▪ and 〈◊〉 such a noise, I coud'n't tell head nor •• ll of the 〈◊〉 , only that he had one 〈…〉
▪

sp.speaker:
FARM ••
▪
sp.p: 〈…〉 was that daughter Sarah?

sp.speaker: SARA • .
sp.p: 〈…〉 this, pray Father, that He 〈…〉 people shall curse 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p:
Does that mean so, Father? I think 〈◊〉 heard Father say that 〈◊〉 would not sell any if they were to live on 〈◊〉 as the Irish 〈◊〉
▪

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p:
Why children▪ children▪ don't you know there's a spiritual meaning to 〈…〉 which we have heard to day? [ 〈…〉 ] He 〈◊〉 hem!—why when Joseph's 〈…〉 down into Egypt to buy 〈…〉 carried silver and 〈◊〉
hem!—and corn was sold for nothing else in scripture times. Hem!—now the true scriptural meaning is hum—why that if poor people come and bring me hard money▪—hem! and I refuse them, why then I'm to be curs'd, but if they have no ha • d money—hem!—I'm not oblig'd to let them have any. I chuse to go always by the true meaning of the bible, boys.

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: I think I have heard Father say, that a square dollar was as good as a round one, and I do really think it is, if we wou'd do what our Hartford paper tells us, I don't remember much on't tho'; but think he call'd it, A Looking Glass.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: A • ! well I remember something of't to —why I'll tell ye, Dan; I have said that it was as good to pay rates with as any, but nothing more; I have got enough for that— why shou'd we be a spending our breath about that which will be of no service to us. Come let's dismiss the table.

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: Ay true enough You, I think it is very needless; do return thanks. Children be still. [Here he proceeds, &c.]

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Well, boys, I feel mightily refresh'd. Come Dan. Joth, come, go out to the barn along with me, and see the oxen I intend to st • ll feed this year, better I believe you never saw.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p: Come so we will, Father. Come Dan.

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: Comes on then.

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.p: Well, sister Sarah, now Father's gone I'll tell you what.

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Well what?

sp.speaker: MAT.
sp.p: Didn't you see our Lyon get hold of the goose's tail? Mother fetch'd him a good kick: Father roll'd his eyes, but c'u'dn't speak, because he was making a beginning. He! he! he!

sp.speaker: SARAH.
sp.p: Well I should laugh'd too if 〈◊〉 had seen it. He! he! he! Be still! Father's coming.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Well, girls, how do you feel after dinner? Come make room! the boys and I have been out to see my oxen, better you never saw, Dan. Say, Joth. don't you think they'll fetch me five pounds a hundred next spring▪

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: Yes, Father, that they will, if the town folks don't rise and take them away, and I am bloody 'fraid they will; and if they should I doubt but the authority would justify them in't.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Why so, why so, Dan?

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: Because the most of 'em an't able to buy at that price.

sp.speaker: WIFE.
sp.p: That wou'd be a fine thing for them to come and take our things without liberty from us.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: If they should I would flail 'em.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p: Well, Father, I believe I must go.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Jack, fetch up the horse.

sp.speaker: JACK.
sp.p: Yesse, Masser.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Come boys, sit down; let's have one good song before you go, and part in peace, as we ought to do on Thanksgiving-Day.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p: Well, that's done Father; do begin, and Dan. and I will sing chorus—what say Dan?

sp.speaker: DAN.
sp.p: With all heart.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Comes on then.

sp.speaker: JOTHAM.
sp.p: Father, be short, I want to go.

sp.speaker: FARMER.
sp.p: Ay, ay—mind the chorus. He, he, h • m.
sp.l: A Cabe of dove's dung on a time it was sold,
For nothing more short than silver and gold;
Silver and gold, silver and gold,
For nothing short of silver and gold.
No, but Jack wou'd persuade and make us think so,
That I am to blame and you my sons too,
You my sons too, you my sons too,
That I am to blame and you my sons too
But now to conclude and I bid you good night▪
I wish you well home, and so a good night:
So a good night, so a good night,
I wish you well home and then a good night.

div.head: A FABLE, By way of an ADDRESS to a COUNTRYMAN, on his petitionin • JUPITER for an Amendment of his Ci ••• mstances.
Not published in the FIRST EDITION.
div.l: HAVE you a friend, look round and spy,
So fond, so prepossess'd as I?
〈◊〉 faults, so obvious to mankind,
My partial eyes could never find.
When, by the breath of fortune blown,
Your airy castles were o'erthrown,
Have I been over prone to blame,
〈◊〉 mortified your hours with shame?
〈◊〉 I e'er known to damp your spirit,
Or twit you with the want of merit?
'Tis not so strange that fortune's frown,
Still perseveres to keep you down.
Look round, and see what others do.
Would you be rich and honest too?
Have you, like those she rais'd to place,
Been opportunely mean and base?
Have you, as times requi • 'd, resign'd
Truth, honour, virtue, peace of mind?
If these are scruples, give her o'er;
Write, practise m •• als, and be poor.
The gifts of fortune truly rate;
Then tell me what could mend your state,
If happiness on wealth were built,
Rich rogues might comfort find in guilt,
As grows the Mis • r's hoarded store,
His fears his wants increase the more.
Think, Peasant, what • ay'n't be the case,
Should fortune take you into grace,
Would that your happiness augment?
What can she 〈◊〉 beyond content?
Suppose yourself a we • lthy heir,
In all the affluence you possess
You might not feel one care the less;
Might you not then, like others, find,
With change of fortune change of mind?
Perhaps, profuse beyond all rule,
Your luxury might break all bounds▪
Plate, table, horses, stewards, hounds,
Might well your debts; then, lust of play
No regal income can defray.
Sunk is all credit, writ • assail,
And doom your future life to jail.
Or were you dignify'd with pow'r,
Would that avert one pensive hour!
You might give avarice its swing,
Defraud a nation, blind a king:
Then, from the hirelings in your cause
Though daily fed with false applause,
Could it a real j • y impart?
Gre • t guilt knew never joy at heart.
I • happiness your point in view?
(I mean th' intrinsic and the true)
She nor in camps or courts resides,
Yet found alike in eve •• sph • re;
Who finds content, will find her there.
O'erspent with • oil, beneath the shade
A Peasant rested on a sp • de.
Good Gods, he cries, 'tis hard to bear
This load of life from year to year!
Soon as the morning streaks the skies,
Industrious labor bids me rise;
With sweat I earn my homely fare,
And ev'ry day renews my care.
Jove hea • d the discontented strain,
And thus rebuk'd the murm'ring swain.
Speak out your wants then, honest friend,
Unjust complaints the Gods offend▪
I • you repine at partial fate,
Instruct me what could mend your state,
Mankind in ev'ry station see.
What wish you? Tell me what you'd be.
So s • id, upborn upon a cloud,
The Peasant saw the anxious croud.
You face of care, says Jove, behold;
His bulky bags are fill'd with gold;
See with what joy he counts it o'er!
That sum to-day hath swell'd his store
Were I that man, the Pe • s • nt •• y'd,
What bl • ssing could I ask beside?
Hold, says the God; first learn to know
True happiness from outward show.
Th • s optic glass of intuition—
Here, take it, view 〈…〉 condition
He look'd, and saw the Miser's breast,
A troubled ocean, ne'er at rest;
Want ever stares him in the face,
And fear anticipates disgrace:
With conscious guilt he saw him start,
Extortion gnaws his throbbing heart,
And never, or in thought or dream,
His breast admits one happy gleam.
May Jove, he cries, reject my pray'r,
And guard my life from guilt and care▪
My soul abhors that wretch's fate.
O keep me in my humble state!
But see, amidst a gaudy croud,
You Minister so gay and proud,
On him what happiness attends,
Who thus rewards his grateful friends▪
First take the glass, the God replies,
Man views the world with partial eyes.
Good Gods! exclaims the startled wight,
Defend me from the hideous sight!
Corruption, with corrosive smart,
Lies cank'ring on his guilty heart;
I see him, with polluted hand,
Spread the contagion o'er the land,
Now av'rice with insatiate jaws,
Now rapine with her harpy claws,
His bosom tears. His conscious breast,
Groans with a load of crimes opprest.
See him, mad and drunk with power,
Stand tott'ring on ambition's tower:
Sometimes, in speeches vain and proud,
His boasts insult the nether croud▪
Now, seiz'd with giddiness and fear,
He trembles lest his fall is near.
Was ever wretch like this, he cries▪
Such misery in such disguise!
The change, O Jove I disavow,
Still be my lot the spade and plough.
He next, confirm'd by speculation
Rejects the Lawyer's occupation:
For he the Statesman seem'd in part,
And bore similitude of heart.
Nor did the Soldier's trade inflame
His hopes with thirst of spoil and fame:
The miseries of war he mourn'd,
Whole nations into desarts turn'd.
By these have laws and rights been brav'd;
By these was free-born man enslav'd:
When battles and invasion cease,
Why swarm they in the lands of peace?
The scythe and civil arms be mine!
Thus, weighing life in each condition,
The Clown withdrew his rash petition.
When thus the God. How mortals err!
If you true happiness prefer,
'Tis to no rank of life confin'd,
But dw • lls in ev'ry honest mind.
Be justice then your sole pursuit,
Plant virtue, and content's the fruit.
So Jove, to gratify the Clown,
Where first he found him set him down
